title: influx of women replaced orkneys ancient genetic code
story: Orkney experienced a wave of immigration during the Bronze Age so large that it replaced most of the local population — and most of the newcomers were women.This groundbreaking revelation comes from research by the Universities of Edinburghand Huddersfield, which published the findings from the ancient DNA analysis on Monday evening.Although male lineages from the original Neolithic population survived for at least another thousand years, by the Iron Age, which followed the Bronze Age, they were largely replaced and are vanishingly rare today.More on these findings, made by a team including Orcadian geneticist Professors Jim Wilson, in The Orcadian — available online and in shops from Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: new company aims to raise 15k for crossroads
story: featured newsNew company aims to raise £k for CrossroadsJanuary ,  at : amOrkney folk are being encouraged to put their eye to the viewfinder, as a new community interest company sets its focus on boosting the county#s creativity while also aiding charity.Orkney Studio CIC is a newly launched community interest company, set up to encourage people to get involved in micro budget independent film-making in Orkney.The company#s aim is to build confidence, develop ambition and enable iniduals and businesses to grow through media. It plans to shoot short and featurefilms, run educational courses as well as other projects that make a dference to the lives of people across Orkney and neighbouring counties. It also wants to offer small charities and good causes in the county an opportunity to work with it, to produce promotional videos and help with marketing.Louise James, volunteer fundraiser, said: “Any profits or activities that the CIC does, that brings money into the organisation, will be re-invested back into the CIC to help our social aims.them.”Arlene Montgomery, manager of Crossroads Care Orkney, said: “We are extremely grateful, and appreciate any donations that Orkney Studio CIC will be making.#These donations will go towards free-of-charge respite care for unpaid carers through our Crossroads Respite Scheme, which provides practical help to unpaid carers in the form of a short respite break.#Other resources that donations help with are things like dementia clocks and other aids.”In the coming weeks, Orkney Studio CIC will be launching one of its first fundraising events.If you are interested in learning more about Orkney Studio CIC, you can visit www.orkney.studio or the Orkney Studio Facebook page.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: new scapa road closed for resurfacing works
story: newsNew Scapa Road closed for resurfacing worksFebruary ,  at : amNew Scapa Road in Kirkwall will be closed between Manse Road and Scapa Court for the next two weeks, Orkney Islands Councilhas confirmed.This comes as road resurfacing works continue in the town and where on the Mainland.As a result of the closure, the section of Pipersquoy Road between New Scapa Road and Broadsands Road will also be closed to through traffic.Signed ersions via Wellington Street High Street, Old Scapa Road and Foreland Road will be in place All bus services will be able to follow the ersion, except the No.  town service bus — it will be unable to serve Pipersquoy and Quoybanks and will travel via Holm Branch Road to re-join the route on Holm Road .The works are being undertaken in two phases to ensure access to the COVID Assessment Centre and Vaccine Centre at the Old Balfour at all times.Access to both car parks centres will be provided internally via a ramped link through the corner of the Old Balfour car park nearest the old Maternity Macmillan entrance. Each phase is expected to take one week. Phase One, from Monday, will see access to both Centres via the old Maternity entrance. These works were originally scheduled for last December, but were postponed by OIC to avoid disrupting the rollout of the COVID- boosters.Other resurfacing works are being undertaken over a substantialof the A between Grimeston Road and Refuge Corner from this Monday for up to seven weeks. Although the majority of works will be carried out under traffic lights, there may be short durations when the road will be closed to carry out works safely.Later this month, works on Broad Street and Palace Road are set to begin. The resurfacing of the fullof Broad Street and the section of Palace Road up to Watergate are being resurfaced is scheduled to begin on February . Full closures will be in place and works are expected to take one week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: papdale nursery closed due to covid related staff shortage
story: Papdale Nursery has been closed this Friday, due to a shortage of staffing in relation to COVID and other sickness.The temporary closure is expected to continue into next Monday, February .Nursery manager, Caroline Easton, said positive COVID cases and the need for isolation due to others becoming symptomatic had led to the unavoidable decision to close. Parents were notied on Wednesday afternoon.Ms Easton said: “We recognise that this is incredibly frustrating for parents who rely on childcare within the nursery, but we have reached the position where closure is unavoidable given the reduced staffing available.#As I’m sure you will appreciate this is a fast-moving situation, but I will continue to update parents of any changes as timely as is possible.“As always we will work through all contingencies to see how a reopening can be managed safely. We thank you for your patience and understanding during these trying times.”All COVID-related situations within schools and nurseries are reviewed on a daily basis by the inter-disciplinary team which includes representatives of NHS Orkney Public Health, the Council’s Education Service, Environmental Health, Safety and Resilience, and affected schools and nurseries.These authorities say it is vital that everyone continues to carry out twice-weekly lateral flow tests and to report the results, where negative, positive or void online here: https:www.nhsinform.scot campaigns coronavirus-covid--report-your-test-result Self-isolating when you are asked to is the best way to prevent the spread of the virus. It’s very important that you stay at home:More information is available from www.nhsinform.scotcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: bruce-mouat-impressed-pretty-relentless-curlers-bounce-back-norway
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Bruce Mouats mens curling teamBruce Mouat’s curling team bounced back from a disappointing start to the day to sink in-form Norway and send a statement of intent on the third day of the round-robin competition in Beijing.Despite a tight - loss to the United States in the morning session, Great Britain looked in top form in the evening session as they swept aside the Norwegians -.Mouat, whose team now have Saturday off before ing for a double-header on Sunday, said: “They are really good side but we’re playing really well and that was clinical, and it was important to bounce back from the defeat to the USA. vw,vw,px, px"Bruce Mouat bounced back from a morning defeat to the United States “This was a really important game for ironing out the kinks in our game, all four of us were firing on all cylinders and that really gives us some momentum.“We controlled the game from the start and established ourselves, we were pretty relentless and never gave up.”Eve Muirhead bemoaned a “frustrating” morning after her team lost their second of three round-robin games - to South Korea. vw,vw,px, px"Eve Muirhead’s team sunk to defeat against South Korea The -year-old looked to have turned the tie in her favour when she stole two in the eighth end, but they gave away four in the next and could not claw back the deficit.“That’s a frustrating one to take,” admitted Muirhead, who next faces an important clash with the United States on Saturday evening.“We’ve got to move on. We’ve only played three games and we’ve been in this position before.“We were in this position in the Olympic qualier where we’d only won one game and lost two, so we know where we are, we know what we’ve got to do and of course we are going to come out tomorrow firing.”We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: british-journalist-detained-afghanistan-released-taliban
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.AfghanistanA British journalist who was being detained by the Taliban in Afghanistan has been released, the PA news agency understands.Former BBC South Asia correspondent Andrew North was being held along with several others by the militant group but has now been freed alongside a second unnamed journalist.Although the UN has not named the journalists released on Friday, PA understands one of them is Mr North.A statement on the UN Refugee Agency Twitter page said: “We are relieved to confirm the release in Kabul of the two journalists on assignment with UNHCR, and the Afghan nationals working with them.We are relieved to confirm the release in Kabul of the two journalists on assignment with UNHCR, and the Afghan nationals working with them.We are grateful to all who expressed concern and offered help.We remain committed to the people of Afghanistan.— UNHCR, the UN Refugee AgencyFebruary , “We are grateful to all who expressed concern and offered help. We remain committed to the people of Afghanistan.”Former Afghan vice president Amrullah Saleh tweeted that Mr North had been “kidnapped” along with eight others from Western countries.His tweet said: “Due to no media, no reporting by citizens  a suffocating atmosphere, corruption, crime  atrocities aren’t well exposed. As an example nine citizens of western countries have been kidnapped amongst them Andrew North of BBC  Peter Juvenal owner of Gandomak Restaurant. Talibs are liars.”A Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office spokesperson added: “We are providing support to the families of a number of British men who have been detained in Afghanistan. UK officials have raised their detention with the Taliban at every opportunity, including when a delegation travelled to Kabul yesterday.”It is thought that Mr North is working for the United Nations high commissioner for refugees in Kabul as a contractor.Articles from his website show despatches from the country over the last few months since the Taliban launched its takeover of the nation in August.Andrew North is working for the UN in Kabul. He is a former colleague and a respected journalist. All inquiries about his situation, which his friends and colleagues are obviously concerned about, should be directed to the UN. https:t.co RuQTwcEYu— Paul DanaharFebruary , A recent piece for BBC Radio  by Mr North documented farmers ing to Marjah in Helmand province sowing opium poppy.He has not posted on his Twitter feed since February .Local news outlet Afghanistan International also reported that he had been taken by the Taliban.A member of a Taliban intelligence unit in Kabul said “several foreign nationals” were arrested in Kabul on charges of working for Western intelligence agencies.When approached for comment, a spokeswoman for the BBC directed PA to a tweet posted by the BBC’s executive editor of world news content Paul Danahar.His tweet said: “Andrew North is working for the UN in Kabul. He is a former colleague and a respected journalist. All inquiries about his situation, which his friends and colleagues are obviously concerned about, should be directed to the UN.”Meanwhile, friends of a second British man who has been detained by the Taliban in Afghanistan have pleaded for his release, saying they believe he may be being held “in error”. vw,vw,px, px"Peter Jouvenal, right, with a mining consultant, collecting potential rock samples in Afghanistan before his arrest Peter Jouvenal, a British German dual national, has been held since early December and was visiting the nation for business and family reasons, his friends said.Mr Jouvenal, a Muslim man who is married to an Afghan woman, has been travelling to Afghanistan for more than  years as a freelance cameraman, businessman and investor.In a statement, sent to the PA news agency on Friday, his friends said: “Peter Jouvenal’s friends are deeply concerned for his safety following his detention by the authorities in Afghanistan in early December.“He is being held without charge, and with no freedom to contact his family or lawyers. vw, px"Peter Jouvenal, left, with Mullah Hafezullah in November “Peter’s family and friends believe that he may have been detained in error, as he was in Afghanistan to discuss investments in Afghanistan’s mining industry as well as conducting family business. Before his arrest he was working openly and had frequent meetings with senior Taliban officials.“We urgently request that the Afghan authorities release Peter. He suffers from high blood pressure and needs medication. There is a high threat of Covid infection in the Afghan prison system.”We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: lassa-fever
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.A man wears latex gloves at a hospitalA hospital patient in Bedfordshire has died from a confirmed case of Lassa fever – the third case to be identied in the UK in the last few days.All three cases of the potentially fatal disease are understood to be linked to recent travel to West Africa.Here, the PA news agency looks at where the virus originated from, what its symptoms are and how transmissible it is.– What is Lassa fever Lassa fever is an acute viral haemorrhagic illness, belonging to the virus family Arenaviridae, that lasts between two and  days, according to the World Health Organisation .The virus, for which there is no approved vaccine, is known to be endemic in Benin, Ghana, Guinea, Liberia, Mali, Sierra Leone, and Nigeria.But it also probably exists in other West African countries as well.– What are the symptoms After starting as a fever with aches and pains, the symptoms can progress to headache, vomiting and diarrhoea.Severe cases can cause victims to bleed from the mouth and nose.– How is it transmitted and is it easy to catch Humans can contract Lassa fever from eating food that has been tainted by the urine or faeces of rodents.The virus, like Ebola, can also be spread through contact with the bodily fluids of a sick person, but it does not spread easily between humans.According to the WHO, there is no epidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread from person to person.– How deadly is Lassa fever Most people with Lassa fever will make a full recovery although severe illness can occur.The overall case-fatality rate is %, according to the WHO.But the observed case-fatality rate among patients who are admitted to hospital with severe cases of Lassa fever is %.Early supportive care with rehydration and symptomatic treatment improves survival chances.– How many cases have there been in the UK The virus was first formally identied in Nigeria in  and no cases were reported in the UK until the s.Since then, there have been  confirmed cases in total, including the three cases identied in the last few days.These cases are the first to have been confirmed in the UK since .In November , three British nationals were brought back to the UK from Sierra Leone for medical assessment after coming into close contact with two people diagnosed with Lassa fever.However, no Lassa fever cases were ultimately confirmed.– How many deaths have there been in the UK Four people have now died from the virus in the UK since , the UK Health Security Agencytold PA.One died in , two died in  and the fourth death was confirmed on Friday.– Where are the current cases in the UK Two cases of the virus were discovered in the east of England on Wednesday.A third was confirmed on Friday in a Bedfordshire hospital but the patient died.– What is the risk to the public The UKHSA said the risk to the public “remains very low”.In a statement, it added: “We are contacting the iniduals who have had close contact with the cases prior to confirmation of their infection, to provide appropriate assessment, support and advice.”We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community title: lassa-fever#comments-anchor
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.A man wears latex gloves at a hospitalA hospital patient in Bedfordshire has died from a confirmed case of Lassa fever – the third case to be identied in the UK in the last few days.All three cases of the potentially fatal disease are understood to be linked to recent travel to West Africa.Here, the PA news agency looks at where the virus originated from, what its symptoms are and how transmissible it is.– What is Lassa fever Lassa fever is an acute viral haemorrhagic illness, belonging to the virus family Arenaviridae, that lasts between two and  days, according to the World Health Organisation .The virus, for which there is no approved vaccine, is known to be endemic in Benin, Ghana, Guinea, Liberia, Mali, Sierra Leone, and Nigeria.But it also probably exists in other West African countries as well.– What are the symptoms After starting as a fever with aches and pains, the symptoms can progress to headache, vomiting and diarrhoea.Severe cases can cause victims to bleed from the mouth and nose.– How is it transmitted and is it easy to catch Humans can contract Lassa fever from eating food that has been tainted by the urine or faeces of rodents.The virus, like Ebola, can also be spread through contact with the bodily fluids of a sick person, but it does not spread easily between humans.According to the WHO, there is no epidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread from person to person.– How deadly is Lassa fever Most people with Lassa fever will make a full recovery although severe illness can occur.The overall case-fatality rate is %, according to the WHO.But the observed case-fatality rate among patients who are admitted to hospital with severe cases of Lassa fever is %.Early supportive care with rehydration and symptomatic treatment improves survival chances.– How many cases have there been in the UK The virus was first formally identied in Nigeria in  and no cases were reported in the UK until the s.Since then, there have been  confirmed cases in total, including the three cases identied in the last few days.These cases are the first to have been confirmed in the UK since .In November , three British nationals were brought back to the UK from Sierra Leone for medical assessment after coming into close contact with two people diagnosed with Lassa fever.However, no Lassa fever cases were ultimately confirmed.– How many deaths have there been in the UK Four people have now died from the virus in the UK since , the UK Health Security Agencytold PA.One died in , two died in  and the fourth death was confirmed on Friday.– Where are the current cases in the UK Two cases of the virus were discovered in the east of England on Wednesday.A third was confirmed on Friday in a Bedfordshire hospital but the patient died.– What is the risk to the public The UKHSA said the risk to the public “remains very low”.In a statement, it added: “We are contacting the iniduals who have had close contact with the cases prior to confirmation of their infection, to provide appropriate assessment, support and advice.”We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community title: northlink donates over 10k to ms charity
story: NorthLink Ferries has donated more than £, to MS Society Scotland after a number of fundraising efforts. organised a sponsored walk from the Lerwick ferry terminal to Scalloway, a quiz, bingo event and horse racing night.Two colleagues also organised a sponsored skye, which is due to take place later this year.Passengers were able to purchase NorthLink Ferries fundraising merchandise, including branded hoodies onboard, or drop spare cash into collection buckets.Over two years NorthLink has raised £, for MS Society Scotland.Kathryn Fullerton from NorthLink Ferries, who led the fundraising activity, said: #We are extremely proud to have raised this amazing amount for MS Society Scotland, a charity that we’ve supported for two consecutive years.#We had lots of fun with all of the fundraising activities but are mainly really pleased that the money will go towards such a fantastic cause and charity.#I’d like to thank everyone who was involved or donated, we couldn’t have done it without you.#..The weather-related disruption that has seen ferry crossings delayed or rescheduled over recent days is set to continue, NorthLink has warned. In its latest service#Further ferry disruption has been announced with Sunday nightrsquos crossing now also subject to delays. title: tobar an dualchais brides day the birthday of
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine or ‘the dead month’.   or Saint Bride’s Day. This falls in with ‘Candlemas’ on nd February as a Christian festival and a traditional end of the Christmas season. Candlemas commemorates the presentation of the infant Jesus at the Temple in Jerusalem as described in St Luke’s Gospel and when some denominations bring candles to their church. Candlemas is also one of the so-called ‘Quarter-days’ marking the changing seasons of winter, spring, summer and autumn. It is followed by Whitsun, Lammas Day and Martinmas as the term-days with their administrative and legal implications for the payment of rents and flittings. Saint Bride or Saint Bridget has been one of the most popular of the saints of the celtic church. Of course, there were many ‘Bridgets’, but the one whose festival date is on st February was ‘Bridget of Kildare’ in Leinster whose death was dated to AD . Bridget was one of the patron saints of Ireland and is remembered in the tradition of plaiting rush crosses around st February to set over doors and windows to protect the home from fire and other danger.   or the endearing ‘Bride’s little fosterling’.’ . ‘Bride’s Day, the birthday of spring’. century, traditions of Saint Bride were collected by Alexander Carmichael among his prayers, hymns, blessings and charms from the Hebrides. He suggests that accounts of Saint Bride were not easily recovered and summarised the tradition: ‘The serpent is supposed to emerge from its hollow among the hills on St Bride’s Day, and a propitiatory hymn was sung to it. Only one verse of this hymn has been obtained, apparently the first. It dfers in dferent localities: [Early on Bride’s mornThe serpent shall come from the hole, I shall not molest the serpent, Nor will the serpent molest me.’ The snake is a powerful element in mythology and religion and a creature to be respected as the ‘hymn’ makes clear. Familiar in the snake coiled round the rod, it is a symbol of medicine and healing, and the appearance of the adder or snake on Saint Bride’s Day offers a feeling of hope and transformation, and of turning the corner with the ening of the days. . century. .!... !

title: special donnie munro concert to bring skye live back with a
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe island#s premier music festival is set toin style on Thursday th May # following a two-year break due to the pandemic # with an opening night extravaganza # ‘Coming Home: An Evening with Donnie Munro and friends’ and featuring special guests in the form of multi-award-winning Gaelic supergroup Mànran.The show will be Donnie’s first in his hometown since  and will see him perform with a full eight-piece band line-up on the spectacular Skye Live Festival site at Am Meall in Portree. The singer said: #This offers me a fantastic opportunity to bring this amazing line-up, featuring some of Scotland’s top musicians together, for an exclusive performance to open this year’s Skye Live Festival.He added: #It has been fantastic to watch the festival grow in strength, year on year, in what must be one of the most special and unique festival locations anywhere in the world, and to see it become internationally recognised as, ‘one of the best boutique festivals in the country’, is just fantastic for the island, and it is such a great honour for me to be invited to be a part of it all and to be bringing the music back home here to where it all began.#Joining Donnie Munro on the night will be Mànran, internationally recognised as one of the most iconic and respected Scottish bands on the road today. With three hugely successful studio albums under their belt, in October  the band released their fourth, titled ÙRAR to critical acclaim, and adding to their success, lead female vocalist, Kim Carnie was crowned ‘Gaelic Singer of the Year’ at the  Hands up for Trad Awards.Mànran founder and accordionist Gary Innes said: #Playing on the Isle of Skye has always been a special night for Mànran over the years but joining Donnie and his band as their special guests for Skye Live will certainly be a night to remember.#.

title: island couple fly the flag for skye in
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineA Skye couple who are embarking on a trip of a letime in Antarctica have proudly flown the official island flag this week while camping at the earth#s southernmost continent.Melanie and Bob Mossfrom Camastianavaig, near Portree, left the island on th January in the first leg of an epic journey which saw them arrive late last week at the landmass which is almost wholly ice-covered, spans . million kilometres, and is located more than , miles south of Skye.Speaking to the Free Press from their camp at Kerr Point, Melanie detailed her and Bob#s incredible voyage so far.She said: #On the th January we flew to Santiago, Chile and arrived in mid-morning of the th. We stayed in quarantine overnight . On the th we flew from Santiago south to Punta Arenas at the tip of Chile to meet our ship.#Melanie and Bob are sailing on the MS Roald Amundsen which is a Hybrid powered expedition ship owned by the Norwegian company Hurtigruten.#We are at sea for  days in total, exploring the Antarctic Peninsula,# she said.#We aren#t exactly known for traditional beach holidays on the Costas, so this voyage was perfect for us. Going to rarely visited places at the end of the earth, to see things only a few other people have ever seen.“It also helps I love penguins.”Melanie said that by sailing by expedition ship, they had the opportunity to explore remote parts of Antarctica on foot and from small zodiac boats, getting close to nature and the beautul wilderness.She added: #We are one of the very few passenger ships to get below the Antarctic Circle this season, so it was a privilege to spend three days down there. The photo of me holding the flag on the balcony below the Antarctic Circle at .° south.#Earlier this week, Melanie alerted the Free Press about their adventure asking: #@WHFP do you know how far any of the fantastic new Skye Flags have travelled  Ours left Camustianavaig with us last month and crossed the Antarctic Circle to ° South and last night we camped with it at Kerr Point Antarctica ° South.#Melanie explained: #I took the flag as it hangs in my ‘den’ at home and when I was researching the trip it was always catching my eye.#It dawned on me one day that I#d be travelling further south than Skye is north and I should take the flag with us. When Bob and I got the opportunity to camp at Kerr Point ° south we just had to fly the flag proudly.”She added: #Only  guests had the opportunity to camp the night in Antarctica, so we were very lucky. Our camp neighbours were from Germany and asked us about the flag as they did not recognise it. We were very proud to explain where we came from and how new the flag is to the Isle of Skye.#I also work seasonally as an instructor at ACE Target Sports, Portree and we have photos of playing cards customers have won at ACE and taken with them around the world. I have taken a couple of ACE#S with me, taken photos and sent them back to Mattto add to the album! So, we are flying the flag for ACE as well.#Melanie and Bob are due to arrive back on Skye next Wednesday #All in all, an epic trip, never to be forgotten and full of amazing memories. Even the eye-wateringly cold Antarctic plunges we have both done down here!# she addedThe couple#s flying of the Skye standard will no doubt be a proud moment for young islander Calum Alasdair Munro from Kilmuir. The youngster’s design was selected as the official flag following a competition which lasted  months, attracted  entries and received more than , public votes.Calum Alasdair raised the flag at an official and socially distant unfurling ceremony at the Nicolson memorial in August .

title: customers at charlie s bar raise 420 for nspcc
story: Charlie’s Bar, in Broughshane Street recently raised an amazing pound for NSPCC Northern Ireland at their popular Monday Club.The funds are in memory of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes and collected at the bar’s weekly afternoon event where customers can enjoy karaoke, food, drinks, and a bit of fun while raising money for charity.Bar owner Charlie Havelin said: “We are very happy to help a great cause.”Susan Smith, Community Fundraising Manager at NSPCC Northern Ireland, said: “We are so grateful to Charlie Havelin and all the members of the Monday Club at Charlie’s Bar for raising this wonderful amount of money for NSPCC Northern Ireland and doing so in the memory of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes who endured unimaginable horrors in his final months.“Arthur’s ordeal touched everyone and this is reflected in the generosity of all those who contributed to this fundraising initiative. Public donations make up most of our income so every pound raised really does make a dference to our work and will help us to support children and families to stop abuse from happening and help them recoverit does.“Now more than ever, it’s important we all look out for the wellbeing of young people. The NSPCC’s helpline is available for any adults who have concerns about a child. Our trained counsellors can be contacted at help@nspcc.org.uk or on   .“Our Childline service is also available around the clock for children to discuss any concerns they have, at childline.org.uk or on  .”

title: coronavirus northern ireland public reflects on the last two years while awaiting full removal of restrictions
story: With the end of Northern Ireland’s Covid- restrictions quickly looming, many people have been reflecting on the last two years of lockdowns, rules and changes.Hospitality businesses are fully open again and Health Minister Robin Swann has been legally advised that he alone cannot lt all remaining limitations sooner than the agreed date of March , including whether risk assessments and vaccine passports will still be necessary in those settings.More people are also ing to the office, but the official Executive advice is still to work from home where possible.Read MoreSwann seeks ministers’ input over Covid relaxations after legal adviceSister of new mum Samantha Willis who died from Covid opens up about her griefWhile being strictly confined to our homes has been undoubtedly tough for many throughout the last  months, some have used the slowing down of society as an opportunity for reflection and a chance to make more time for other things in le.Ian McNie from Coleraine said he has missed being able to go to church and the gym, but he has “been able to spend more time with the family, which has been positive”.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseIan McNie FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIan McNie“I’ve been able to do a lot of things around the house that I wouldn#t otherwise have done. I’ve been able to reflect on le and the important things. Just being busy and working all the time is not the best thing to be doing,” he added.John Kayes, who works in Belfast city centre, is looking forward to coming out the other end of the pandemic and restrictions for good.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseJohn Kayes FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueJohn Kayes“I just want to get back to normal and forget about the whole thing. It has been really tough. My dad suffers from dementia and he has suffered a big decline in the last two years. That has been a hard one to swallow,” he said.Mr Kayes said he and his loved ones have “adopted new habits such as spending family time together and that#s probably one of the best things about it”, but apart from that, maintains he won’t miss any aspects of the last two years.“I’ve been in work since early May, after five weeks of furlough, and my we has been working all the way through. She#s a school teacher so she has been in school throughout. In work, it was almost like a parallel universe.“Things seemed normal-ish in the office, then you were coming out and it was like a ghost town. In work, nothing really changed apart from wearing masks.”Arlene Wright, from east Belfast, was glad to get some long overdue chores done during lockdown, but after ing to the cinema for the first time in what felt like forever, she doesn’t think she could go back to lockdown le.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseArlene Wright FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueArlene WrightShe said: “It’s good to see we’re coming out. During the pandemic I would have painted the house and done dferent things like that with nothing but time to do it, but I’ll not be doing all that now. I miss getting out for a drink and going for a meal. I can#t wait to get out.”Nicole Bratton from Co Fermanagh started university during the early days of Covid. She has now nearly finished her degree in veterinary science at the University of Nottingham and reminisced on having to perform animal assessments virtually.“I started university online in England and had to stay home until the summer. It was hard to make friends, but it made you closer with people in your year because we were all going through the same thing,” she said.“It’s made me better at doing tasks online. We had to do online practicals with people livestreaming their horses, walking them up and down. I suppose it has made us better at knowing the smaller signs because you can’t see them in real le, to try to decide whether it#s an emergency or not.”Rachel Cummins and Hannah Irvine are both in their third year of studies at Queen’s University.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseNicole Bratton, Rachel Cummins and Hannah Irvine FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNicole Bratton, Rachel Cummins and Hannah Irvine“It has been mad because obviously the year we started is when Covid happened,” Hannah said.“There are still people on my course that I haven’t met and probably won’t ever meet, so it’s kind of bittersweet, but this semester we’ve been in a good bit more and it’s good to be back. I can’t believe it has been two years. It feels like so much has happened, but nothing has happened at the same time.”The students added how they feel their university experiences have been “stolen” from them in a way.“I think our age group was hit very hard. We were renting a house in second year and had to pay for it and we were never even in university, but there were four of us in the house so at least we were able to see people,” added Rachel.It’s safe to say that many have tried to make the most out of a global pandemic, with better time management and a renewed appreciation for their loved ones. However, it’s now clear that the public can’t wait to get back to normal again.Most ReadFamous London restaurant The Ivy to open eaterie in Belfast city centreKill protocol or the Union is finished, Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium BBC NI presenters topping up pay packets with money-spinning external engagementsAppearance fees paid out to local TV’s household names revealedExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseBarra BestMark Simpson. Credit: Paul McErlaneMark Carruthers FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBarra BestAdrian RutherfordTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailWell-known faces from BBC NI appear on a new list revealing stars’ lucrative earnings from work outside the corporation.Eleven local personalities are named on the latest external events register, which details fees received on top of their BBC salaries in recent months.Read MoreDonna Traynor discrimination case against BBC set to open on ThursdayLeading BBC journalists across the UK accepted  ‘outside’ jobs last year, including speaking engagements and chairing events.Payments are listed on the register, published quarterly as part of the BBC’s commitment to impartiality and transparency.The register puts fees into four categories below £,, £, to £,, £, to £,, and more than £,. No specic amounts are given, but most fees relating to BBC NI names are at the lowest end of the scale.The latest register, covering October to December , includes BBC NI names such as Barra Best, Mark Simpson and John Campbell.Mr Best, a presenter and weatherman, appeared at six events during the three-month period.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up One involved hosting a Construction Employers Federation event, and he received a fee of ‘between £, and £,’.Mr Best’s other events are listed at ‘below £,’ and include events at Belfast City Council and at JPI Media.Mr Simpson, a senior journalist, features five times across the same period — his fees are all listed at ‘below £,’.His duties included chairing a  at a Hospitality Exchange and Tourism Bodies event, hosting a Newry Chamber of Commerce and Trade event and chairing a  at Queen’s University.Mr Campbell, BBC NI’s business and economics editor, has four entries, including hosting an Agenda NI event and acting as moderator at an Institute of Directors event — each fee was under £,.Presenter Jo Scott is listed three times — at two Tourism NI meetings and one at JPI media. Each fee was under £,.Mark Carruthers, host of The View and Sunday Politics, appears twice — presenting an event at Londonderry Chamber of Commerce and chairing a  at the NI Confederation for Health  Social Care. Both drew fees between £, and £,.Jayne McCormack, a political correspondent, hosted a Northern Ireland Local Government Association meeting. Her fee was under £,.Clodagh Rice, a business reporter, hosted Fintech Envoy and PropertyPal events. Both fees were under £,.Marie-Louise Connolly, BBC health correspondent, hosted a Women’s Aid event — her fee was under £,.Ireland correspondent Emma Vardy was an interviewer at a Libraries NI event. Her fee is also listed at under £,.Presenter Declan Harvey hosted a PeaceIV event, while Louise Cullen, BBC NI’s environment reporter, was host at an Actions Renewable meeting. Both their fees were under £,.UK names on the list include Emily Maitlis, the lead anchor of Newsnight. She is believed to have earned at least £, during the year for external events, on top of her £, salary.BBC Breakfast presenter Naga Munchetty, who is paid more than £, a year, could have also taken home at least £, across the year on top of her standard salary.Clive Myrie and Dan Walker could have earned more than £, and £,, respectively, in external earnings on top of their £, and £, BBC salaries.Huw Edwards, who is the BBC’s highest-paid news presenter with a salary of up to £,, earned at least £, from four outside engagements during .Razia Iqbal, presenter of Radio ’s The World Tonight, was the busiest BBC presenter, with  jobs in addition to her work for the corporation during  — the majority of her fees were under £,.A BBC spokesperson said: “The register was introduced on January , , as part of a package of impartiality measures and details paid-for external work by staff in on-air journalism roles and senior leaders.“Data from this quarter show % of external events undertaken by staff involved payments of under £, and the overwhelming majority — % — were below £,.“All the events listed were approved prior to being undertaken and meet the BBC’s rigorous editorial guidelines.“The external events register forms part of the BBC’s renewed commitment to ensure the highest standards of impartiality across the organisation.”Related topicsBelfast City CouncilQueen’s UniversityMore On Belfast City CouncilBelfast City council set to launch legal action over Poots’ port checks move PremiumHolyland residents instruct Belfast law firm to take legal action against PSNI, council and Stormont department PremiumGail WalkerOpinionThe idea NI’s dficulty is nationalism’s opportunity is corrosive... Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumChanges to Covid restrictions may force thousands of vulnerable people to retreat even moreLisa SmythFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailAll remaining Covid restrictions in England, including the requirement to self-isolate, could be scrapped this month — and Northern Ireland might not be far behind.It’s not quite cut and dried though, with the political crisis here playing into the equation.Current restrictions in England, which are due to expire on March , mean anyone who tests positive must self-isolate for at least five days. However, the Prime Minister — currently on a charm offensive as part of a mission to restore his reputation — has said he expects the last domestic rules in England could end earlythe data permits. Boris Johnson made the announcement on Wednesday, as Robin Swann was still waiting for an expert assessment on whether he can press ahead with lting restrictions in Northern Ireland.Read MoreRobin Swann has ‘no plans’ to ditch Covid testing and isolation rules in NIEarlier this week, the Health Minister told a press briefing that he wants to lt most, “ not all” remaining measures. Key to all of this, however, is the legal and public health advice he receives. It is understood that even as late as Wednesday night he hadn’t been given the green light to press ahead with relaxations and it isn’t entirely clear what this will entaillawyers tell him he has the power to act without Executive approval. If this proves to be the case, Mr Swann then has to decide which restrictions he will lt.Among the rules that remain are the controversial Covid certicate scheme for nightclubs, a minimum self-isolation period for people who test positive, a legal requirement to wear face coverings in indoor public spaces, and the regular use of lateral flow tests. Given Mr Johnson’s comments on Wednesday, there was hope that Mr Swann would follow suit, but a spokeswoman from the Department of Health on Wednesday night poured cold water on any such suggestion. “There are no immediate plans for changes to the current arrangements for testing, contact tracing and isolation in Northern Ireland,” she said. “All aspects of test and trace are kept under active review.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up However, while this may be Mr Swann’s preferred position, his hands may be forced on the matterMr Johnson scraps lateral flow testsin England. To date, NI’s supply has come from England and it will be dficult for the UUP minister to make a case to the public that they should pay for LFTs as it is unlikely Westminster will pay outthey aren’t in use across the water. The only other alternative would be for Stormont to pick up the cost — and given the current political instability, it’s anyone’s guess whether that would even be possible.As it stands, Covid- is still re in Northern Ireland.Given current testing arrangements, the actual number of positive cases is likely to be signicantly higher than those on the Department of Health’s dashboard. Realistically, how many people are actually recording positive LFT results Mercully, Omicron has not turned out to be as dangerous as first feared — at least to most people. But there are still tens of thousands of people here who are clinically extremely vulnerable and for whom the vaccinations may not provide effective protection.Many have had to shield and make extraordinary sacrices to stay safe over the past two years. While the wider population is looking forward to a e to normal, it is these very changes and relaxations that will force the clinically vulnerable to retreat even more from the world.Related title: half term holidays in northern ireland a guide to the best family fun days
story: Ulster Museum. Picture: PA"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland df .ece AUTOCROP w ni_science_festival.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland df .ece AUTOCROP w ni_science_festival.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "A guide to the best family events taking place across Northern Ireland during half term.  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueUlster Museum. Picture: PAAllan PrestonTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailWith half-term approaching, the Belfasthas rounded up the best family fun days on offer – from puddle jumping championships and chocolate making workshops to movies at the museum, there’s no shortage of activities.Read MoreSpain scraps ban on unvaccinated UK children ahead of half-term holidaysBelfastThe NI Science FestivalWith the NI Science Festival taking place between February -, the curators have promised “an interstellar” programme that includes  public events across the country covering everything from biochemistry to physics and ecology.Twitter! After seemingly a web server overload, we#re delighted to announce the  programme for #NISF is now fully online! Over  events across NI and online celebrating the Science, The Universe and Everything in Between! Book now and often - https:t.co vVWpfTBFsd pic jBjxvMM— NI Science FestivalJanuary , BODY – Botanic Gardens, Thursday th to Sunday th, from pm-pmTicket are £, or £ for a group.At Botanic Gardens, the BODY event offers an atmospheric outdoor installation exploring human biology using light, special effects, sound and fire.Using cutting-edge technology to create a deeper understanding of the science of the human form, BODY has been designed to inspire young and curious minds. An outdoor, nighttime event for all ages. Visitors are encouraged to wrap up warm.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Kick sampling session. Free event in Orangefield Park on Thursday, Feb  at am, am and pmOn the Connswater Community Greenway, families have been invited to find out what lies beneath our rivers.The “kick sampling” session, run by Eastside Partnership Greenway Leaders in the Knock River at Orangefield Park, lets children and big kids get their wellies on for an interactive experience to identy species.Films at the Museum – Osmosis Jones, Ulster Museum on Thursday, Feb  from am to .pmTickets £.For a movie matinee in a unique setting that doesn’t break the bank, Osmosis Jones is a cutting-edge, live action animated action adventure comedy about one white blood cell#srace against the biological clock to hunt down and destroy a lethal new virus . Bill Murray stars as Frank, in whose body the action unfolds.Irish FA tours – Windsor Park, Monday Feb  to Friday Feb , am to pmTicket prices £. to £..At the home of Northern Ireland football in Windsor Park, sporting fans can relive the atmosphere of match day, gain insights into the drama on and off the pitch and “feel the rush of emotions shared by everyone inside the stadium”.Perfect for visitors from schoolchildren to grandparents, the Education and Heritage Centre at the National Football Stadium at Windsor Park tells the unique story of Northern Irish football with a mix of media, immersive physical interactive activities and key artefacts from the s to the present day.Stuff! With Maddie Moate – The Mac, Belfast. Friday Feb  and Saturday Feb  at am and pmTickets £.Bafta-winning children’s TV presenter and YouTuber Maddie Moate brings a selection of stories from her debut book Stuff! to le on stage.Stuff! is packed with extraordinary tales of the ingenious ways people around the world, and across history, have made, used and re-used the stuff around them, inspiring a passion for sustainability in children and adults alike.Co DownPuddle jumping championships, Castle Espie. Friday to Sunday, Feb -, from am to .pmTickets £. for adults and £. for children.On the banks of Strangford Lough and a few miles from Comber, the wetlands at Castle Espie is seeking to make a splash for the half term break.The puddle jumping championships will see families grab their wellies to take part in a nationwide competition being held at wetland centres across the UK.Children and adults can perfect their splashing techniques in the ‘practice zones’ before taking part in the daily competitions. With prizes up for grabs for ‘super-splashers’, other activities include welly wanging and a mini assault course.Pottery painting fun. Eden Pottery, Millisle, from am to pm on Tuesday, Feb  to Saturday Feb Families are invited to create their own masterpieces this half term in a fun pottery painting class on the Ards Peninsula.After a quick demonstration on how to paint with sponges, you can soon have your very own piece of custom pottery to take home. An on-site cafe completes the experience and booking is advisable.Hillsborough Castle – The Wonderful World of Honeybees. Saturday Feb  at .am, .am, pm and pmA free workshop is included in the admission price, £. per adult, £. for children and £. concession. Spaces are limited and on a first come, first served basis.At Hillsborough Castle, a workshop led by beekeeper Gwen Earnshaw will teach children about the wonderful world of honeybees, their role as pollinators and how they make honey out of waxcomb. Beekeeping equipment will be on display and visitors can taste honey made by Hillsborough Castle’s very own honeybees.Castlewellan Forest Park and Peace MazeIn Castlewellan Forest Park, families can enjoy a stunning outdoor location with a view of the Mournes and countless activities to enjoy.The walking trail around Castlewellan Lake boasts a Victorian Castle, one of the most outstanding tree and shrub collections in Europe, as well as a km mountain bike trail.For younger children, there is an onsite multi-activity centre, hedge maze and equestrian centre making it a must-visit for all ages. Entrance fees apply.Ulster Transport Museum, Holywood. Open Tuesdays to Sundays from am to pmTickets are £. for adults and £. for children. Pre-booking is essential.A chance to journey through time and discover Northern Ireland’s story of transport and social change.Described as “a unique place for the dreamers and doers of tomorrow”,  the museum hopes to inspire with the story of the “engineering giants” of this country.A brand new exhibition features the museum’s much-loved Delorean and a host of new, interactive experiences.Co ArmaghCosmic Tales – Armagh Planetarium, Friday, Feb , at am and pmTickets £.Hosted at Armagh Planetarium and part of the NI Science Festival, Cosmic Tales offers “a mesmerising interactive session” for children that reveals the wonders of the Cosmos.The sessions are delivered by an experienced physics communicator and busker – astrophysicist Dr Liz Conlon who shares her extensive knowledge and passion about the universe in a fun and illuminating way.Navan Centre Tour. Killylea Road, Armagh. Open all year round with tours at .pm on Tuesdays to SundaysPrices for tours are £ for adults and £ for children. Pre-booking is highly recommended.Navan Centre  Fort gives a vivid glimpse into le in Ireland , years ago. As the ancient seat of Kings and home of the Red Branch Knights, the legendary Emain Machais known as one of Ireland’s most famous and important archaeological sites.Customers are welcome to arrive an hour before their scheduled tour time to see an audio-visual show on the Tales of the Ulster Cycle, visit the exhibition space and the archeo play area for children.Armagh County Museum, the Mall ArmaghFree admission and open Monday to Saturday from am to pm.This is the oldest county museum in Ireland, officially opening in . The museum holds a broad collection of objects, art and archival material that chronicle the story of the people who have lived and worked in Co Armagh throughout the centuries.Oxford Island  Lough Neagh Discovery Centre, CraigavonFree admission and open from am to pm.Located on the south-eastern shores of Lough Neagh, much of the area around Oxford Island is designated as a national nature reserve due to the importance of local habitats like reed beds, open water, wildle ponds, forests and wildflower meadows.Facilities inlcude a network of all-access walking trails, bird-watching hides, the Lough Neagh Discovery Centre, Kinnego Marina and the Kinnego Bushcraft Centre.Half term kids camps at the Richill Recreation CentreDance camp sessions are available on Monday, Feb  and Wednesday Feb .The sessions for five to eight-year-olds on each day are from  to pm, and from .pm to .pm for nine to -year-olds.Soccer camp is on Wednesday, Feb  from  to am for ages five to eight and from .am to .pm for ages nine to .Co LondonderryStreet art stencilling with UV Arts, The Playhouse. Saturday February , am to .pmTickets £.Learn the art of stencilling and graffiti with the creative team behind the famous Derry Girls mural. As part of the NI Sustainability Fair, the “action-packed workshop” will demonstrate how to design and develop bespoke street art stencils. Students can learn the history of the street art movement and the importance of innovative street art in public places.Kid#s half term chocolate making workshop, Castlerock.  Wednesday Feb  at  to pm, Thursday Feb  at -pm, Saturday Feb  at -pmTickets are £ per child.Taking place at “The Chocolate Manor” on  Main Street, the chocolate making workshop is billed as “the tastiest half term experience on the north coast”.In this one-hour kids-only experience, participants will get to make three “fabulous chocolate creations” using the finest Belgian chocolate. After enjoying a hot chocolate, children will get to bring their creations home to enjoy.Big Hero , films at the Nerve Centre on Magazine Street in Derry. Thursday February , am to .pmTickets £.Academy Award-winning animated comedy by Walt Disney studios. Big Hero  sees -year-old troubled genius Hiro Hamada delve into the outlandish world of inventing robots.NI Science Festival Sustainability Fair. The Playhouse, LondonderryFree event, no booking required.The NISF Sustainability Fair brings together a range of local, national and international organisations to demonstrate practical ways ways in which they are trying to make a real dference for the planet and what young people living here can do to lend a hand. With a number of workshops on offer, the event is suitable for all ages.Shark and Skate Egg Case Hunt, Downhill Beach. Saturday, February  from .pm to .pmLocated close to the north coast’s iconic shoreline overlooked by Mussenden Temple, the Shark and Skate Egg Case Hunt at Downhill Beach offers the chance to search for the egg cases of sharks, skates and rays.It’s part of efforts to protect these endangered creatures through Ulster Wildle’s Sea Deep project. By becoming “a citizen scientist”, the workshop lets children get involved in local shark conservation without even getting wet.Co AntrimWonderland Wood Trail, Antrim Castle Gardens. Running until November from am to pmTickets are £ for a familyand £ for inidual adults and £ for children. Booking essential.At Antrim Castle Gardens, there’s a chance for all ages and four-legged friends to experience the magic of the Wonderland Wood interactive Fairy Tale.The “enchanting trail” around the gardens includes less well known paths and places with an interactive booklet providing clues along the way.The BFG in pictures. Flax Gallery, Theatre at the Mill. Mossley Mill, NewtownabbeyFree admission and open from am to pm on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday Friday. Wednesday from am to pm, am to pm on Saturday and am to pm on Sunday.The BFG in Pictures is an exhibition from House of Illustration, curated by famed illustrator Quentin Blake. The exhibition features  reproductions from Roald Dahl’s much-loved story and shows a fascinating insight into the collaboration between the author and illustrator.Splash, Bounce  Swing – Half term activities from £ across four leisure centres Antrim Forum, Crumlin, Six Mile and ValleyIncludes swimming, soft play, racquet sports and bouncy castles. A range of fun activities for little ones are on offer this half term from Monday Feb  to Friday Feb . All activities are subject to availability.The Wizard of Oz, Theatre at the Mill, Mossley Mill, Newtownabbey. Thursday Feb  to Saturday February  at .pm and Sunday Feb  at .pmPresented by the Home Spun Musical Theatre Group after months of rehearsals, The Wizard of Oz invites audience to follow the Yellow Brick Road with Dorothy, Toto and all the amazing characters she meets along the way. Giant’s CausewayOpening times from Monday, February  are from dawn to dusk along the coastline and from am to pm at the car park and visitor centre.One of the undisputed gems of Northern Ireland tourism, the Giant’s Causeway continues to delight visitors from abroad and locals alike.The full visitor experience includes on-site parking, guided tours, hand-held audio guides, access to the visitor Ccentre’s exhibition and interpretation area, the shop cafe and use of all facilities.Prices are £ per adult, £. for children or £. for a family ticket or £. for a one-adult family.Co FermanaghMarble Arch Caves, EnniskillenFor a guided cave tour, pricing is £ for adults and £ for children.Marble Arch Caves Visitor Centre is open from am to pm, with guided cave tours from .am to pm on Monday to Friday as well as .am to .pm on weekends.The Marble Arch Caves reveal an “underworld labyrinth” tracing the journey of the Owenbrean River through a living cave. Children under  must be accompanied by an adult and those under four go free but still require a ticket.Share Discovery Village, Lisnaskea Road, EnniskillenBilled as Ireland’s largest residential outdoor activity centre, a packed schedule of mid term activities is running from Saturday, Feb  to Tuesday, Feb .The most popular activities include combat corps, mountain biking, bush craft, canoeing and lots more. Spacious self-catering accommodation is also available for the entire family.Cuilcagh Boardwalk Trail , Marlbank Road, LegnabrockyFor a more active day out with the family, the stunning Cuilcagh Boardwalk Trail meanders through one of the largest expanses of blanket bog in Northern Ireland, traversing over tracks, boardwalk and a now famous staircase.  A full information guide on accessing the site is available online.Florence Court, EnniskillenThe grounds of the scenic Florence Court estate will be open on weekdays from am to pm from Monday Feb . On weekends, the tea room and visitor centre are also open from am to pm.Operated by the National Trust, the th century stately home of Florence Court is surrounded by lush parkland and the majestic countryside of west Fermanagh.Enniskillen CastleEnniskllen Castle Visitor Centre is open from .am to pm on weekdays and am to pm on weekends. Admission into the visitor centre is free, and for access to the historic castle site and museums is £ for adults and £. for children.Co TyroneOM Exhibition Tour and Odyssey Film Experience, Om Dark Sky Park  Observatory, OmaghPrices for guided tours £ and the outdoor Odyssey film experience is £. Full schedule available online.Daily guided tours offer a star hop across the universe with an interactive exhibition linking the landscape with the astronomical and archaeological heritage of the Sperrins. This is followed by a film projection on to the outside of the Observatory building.Peatlands Park, DungannonSituated near the shores of Lough Neagh, Peatland Park promises plenty of “wilderness appeal” with visitors able to experience both peatland and woodland habitats and amazing views of the wildle. Reed buntings, cuckoos, red and grey squirrels, badgers and hares are among the wide range of animals that can be seen here.Ulster American Folk Park, OmaghOpen am to pm from Tuesday to Friday and am to pm on weekends. Tickets are £. for adults and £. for children. Pre-booking is recommended. Visitors can follow in the footsteps of the brave emigrants who set sail for the New World in the th and th centuries.Parkanaur Forest Park, DungannonOpen daily from am to dusk, free access.Home to a herd of white fallow deer, Parkanaur boasts a nature trail through oak and beech trees that passes a Victorian garden, wishing well and old archway.The Argory, MoyGrounds are open all year round from am to pm. House, cafe and shop open at weekends from am to pm.Built in the s, The Argory and its hillside location enjoy wonderful views over the gardens and a -acre wooded estated bordering the River Blackwater. Most ReadFamous London restaurant The Ivy to open eaterie in Belfast city centreKill protocol or the Union is finished, TUV chief tells rally‘Teebane is the forgotten atrocity’: Family title: stena line astonished by volume of applicants for new irish sea crossing jobs
story: The Stena Embla, which made its first sailing across the Irish Sea last year. Photo: Kelvin Boyes Press EyeKelvin Boyes   Press Eye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Stena Embla, which made its first sailing across the Irish Sea last year. Photo: Kelvin Boyes Press EyeEmma DeighanTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA job advertisement selling “A Le Less Ordinary” as a staff member on board Stena Line has attracted , applications.The applications apply to posts which form part of a campaign to recruit  staff for the ferry company’s Irish Sea routes.They were promoted online as part of the firm’s new campaign which sells the roles as having the ideal work le balance.This includes work patterns that offer % time-off for those who want to live and work on board the vessels for one or two-week shts and then spend equal time off.The positions available are part of the Onboard Sales and Servicesteam, with vacancies for service assistants and chefs.The campaign was launched last month for those seeking a new career in . Stena Line said it had hoped for a favourable response but said, “Even the most optimistic of predictions could not have expected it to be so over-subscribed”.The company has now undertaken the initial stage of the selection process and, for the first-time, is hosting two Open Days for prospective candidates on Monday, February , where they will get a chance to meet members of Stena Line’s crews.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The Open Days are taking place in Belfast and Birkenhead with the latter being held onboard one of Stena Line’s newest ferries, Stena Edda, to give candidates a chance to get a first-hand taste of le onboard on the Irish Sea”.Stephen Bryden, Stena Line’s head of onboard sales and services, said: “I am astonished by the public’s response to the A Le Less Ordinary recruitment campaign. We have never received so many applications.“It really goes to show how many people are attracted to a le at sea with a company like Stena Line. Now our HR team has the challenge of how to sort and interview so many applicants, but that is a nice challenge to have. Thank you to every single person that has applied to work with us.Stena Line is the largest ferry operator on the Irish Sea, with the biggest fleet offering the widest choice of routes including, combined passenger and freight services from Belfast to Cairnryan and Liverpool, Dublin to Holyhead, and Rosslare to Fishguard routes, as well as a freight only route from Belfast to Heysham, a total of up to  weekly sailing options between Britain and Ireland. Stena Line also offers a direct service from Rosslare to Cherbourg with  crossings per week.It is one of Europe#s leading ferry companies with  vessels and  routes in Northern Europe.The company is family-owned and was founded in . It is headquartered in Gothenburg. Stena Line is part of the Stena AB Group, which has , employees and an annual turnover of around  billion SEK.Most ReadFamous London restaurant The Ivy to open eaterie in Belfast city centreKill Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium ‘Teebane is the forgotten atrocity’: Family call for public inquiry into IRA massacre of eight menSister of young workman murdered in IRA roadside bomb  years ago says it’s time families were given answersExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseRuth Forrest attends the memorial service at the site of the Teebane massacre which claimed eight lives, including her brother David Harkness FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRuth Forrest attends the memorial service at the site of the Teebane massacre which claimed eight lives, including her brother David HarknessSuzanne BreenTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA woman whose brother was murdered in the Teebane Massacre has called for a public inquiry into Northern Ireland’s “forgotten atrocity”.Ruth Forrest said families of the eight men killed were deeply disturbed that nobody had been brought to justice for the IRA bomb  years ago.“We have many unanswered questions,” she said. “Nobody has ever been convicted in connection with Teebane. No charges have ever been brought.“We know that out of  suspects from the planning of the bomb to its execution, six weren’t even questioned by police. There are many issues we’d like addressed and I believe they merit a public inquiry.“At the very least, I think we deserve a fresh inquest as the original one, in our view, did not resolve some matters for us. The  HETreport left us with more questions than answers.”Ms Forrest’s brother David Harkness, a -year-old joiner, was killed with seven others.The eight men had left work at Lisanelly Army base in Omagh and were travelling in a Ford Transit van towards Cookstown when a roadside bomb exploded at Teebane crossroads on January , .!forfort[r].style.e.data["datawrapper-height"][a]+"px"Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The company employing them, Karl Construction, was targeted because it carried out work for the security forces.Three weeks later, the UDA shot dead five men in Sean Graham’s bookies in the Lower Ormeau area of Belfast, alleging it was in retaliation for Teebane. The five Belfast murders were examined in a -page Police Ombudsman’s report published on Tuesday.Ms Forrest said: “I will never forget the Sean Graham’s shooting. It made me sick to the pit of my stomach that anyone would claim it had anything to do with us.“It wasn’t done in our name. We were in deep trauma at the time. We did not want anyone  to be put in that place. It’s something I wouldn’t wish on my worst enemy.“Neither our family, nor any of the Teebane families, wanted retaliation. I would love the opportunity to meet the Lower Ormeau families and tell them that personally.”Ms Forrest said she welcomed victims of any atrocity making progress in their campaign for justice and hoped that the Teebane families could also make advances.“Sometimes I feel like Teebane is the forgotten atrocity,” she said. “I can’t understand why. It was one of the biggest single losses of le in the Troubles.“Given that there have been no convictions, I am perplexed as to why there isn’t more clamour about it.“I feel we need to remind everybody that eight men were murdered — that they were eliminated because of the legitimate jobs they did.“It can be very hurtful when Teebane passes under the radar. It feels to us that our loved ones lives were less valuable than others’, that there is a hierarchy of victims in Northern Ireland.”Ms Forrest said that unionist politicians were not active enough in pursuing justice issues.“I look across the political ide, and I see Sinn Fein championing the Bloody Sunday, Ballymurphy and a whole range of other cases,” she said.“I think unionist politicians have let us down. They’re not out there calling for action on Teebane. Nobody seems to be fighting for us. I’m very disappointed that pressure isn’t being brought to bear in terms of our justice campaign.“Nobody seems to be doing the right thing by our family and the other Teebane families.”Ms Forrest said her brother had been working in Australia for two years, but he ed to Northern Ireland because their mother was seriously ill.“There was no Skype or Zoom in those days. We didn’t think mammy would make it. David wanted to see her so he came back.“Mammy lived and he didn’t. She always said, ‘God brought David home to die’.“After mammy recovered, he started saving up money to go back to Australia. It was hard to get work as a joiner. He took a job with Karl Construction. He kept that very much to himself but we knew he was working on the Army base in Omagh.”Seven men, including David, died outright. They were Gary Bleeks , Cecil Caldwell , Robert Dunseath , Richard McConnelland Nigel McKee . The van’s driver Oswald Gilchristdied in hospital four days later.Ms Forrest said her brother was the youngest of six in their family, and the only son.“We always used to joke that it would be a brave woman who came to take him away from all his sisters.“Little did we no there would never be the chance of that happening,” Ms Forrest said.“David was a lovely, decent hard-working country lad. He didn’t have a political bone in his body. We were brought up in a Christian home to love our neighbours and respect everybody. We never thought we had any enemies.“He was a joiner doing a day’s work —that shouldn’t have put a target on his back.”Most ReadFamous London restaurant The Ivy to open eaterie in Belfast city
